w_def: terms related to fundamental principles of Ayurveda
science where advantageous and disadvantageous, happy and unhappy (states of) life along with what is good and bad for life, its measurement and life itself are described
combination of the body, sense organs, mind and soul
the sustenance of life or the aspect of life which prevents decay
that which keeps the body alive
continuous or uninterrupted process of life
continuity of result in the form of life due to the association of body, sense organs, mind and soul; which transmigrates from one body to another
Four patterns of lifestyle viz., wholesome, unwholesome, happy and unhappy
lifestyle which is beneficial to the self and the society
lifestyle which is neither beneficial for the society nor for the self
a lifestyle which provides comfort for the self
a lifestyle which results in sorrow/pain
the science and knowledge of life, which describes all substances of the universe in terms of their being beneficial, harmful, pleasant and unpleasant to life.
A synonym of āyurveda. The entire subject matter of āyurveda can be categorized into three categories viz., 1. hetu (causes) 2. liṅga auṣadha (therapeutics)

one of the eight branches of āyurveda which deals with the cause, conditions, symptoms, progress and cure of the ailments afflicting the body. The treatment is usually aimed at correcting kāyāgni and thereby alleviating the diseases mostly physic
one among the eight branches of āyurveda which deals with health and morbidity of the children and the nursing mother
one of the eight branches of āyurveda which deals with the effects of the organic and inorganic poisons on the human body and their management.
one of the eight branches of āyurveda which deals with treatment of possession and other physical and mental illness
one of the eight branches of āyurveda which deals with diseases of eye, ear, nose, throat and head. [also called as shālākyatantra]

w_trans: treatment to remove foreign body/ surgery
w_def: one of the eight branches of āyurveda which deals with removal of foreign body, wounds and other surgical conditions
one of the eight divisions of āyurveda which deals with retardation of ageing changes and sustaining healthy cognitive and intellectual faculties till the end of complete human life span
one of the eight branches of āyurveda dealing with sustenance of sexual vigour and obtaining healthy progeny
way of seeing and understanding the world.
classic, scripture, science, branch of knowledge; synonym of āyurveda

w_trans: criteria for critical evaluation of technical texts
w_def: devices, that are necessary to understand, criticise and evaluate a technical treatise

w_trans: extended application of the already stated concept; analogy
w_def: such statements of the author permitting incorporation of useful knowledge described in a different context

consideration of earlier observations; methods of referring back to the earlier portion of the book for information on a particular subject without which the present topic cannot be understood properly
the main theme on which the entire science is build; or context of elucidation or discussion

w_trans: the statement that points to prospective reference
w_def: situation wherein the author at times introduces certain topics in advance, which are described later in detail elsewhere
statements of agreement with the opinion of others
agreement to various diverse opinions at the same time; without confirmation
statements which point out the definite cause for an effect and that such a cause as indispensable
statements which indicate or include an exception to a general rule; final beatitude, the final deliverance of the soul from bondage of matter
presumption; statements made in such a manner which gives room for inferences of a different meaning
concise statement; statements briefly enunciating a theme or an object
statements which are reaffirmed after refuting the views of others
authoritative instructions; statements of enlightened persons which are in the form of advice or injunction

w_trans: analytical thinking of mind leading to decision; a kind of speculation; entity of mind (manas)
w_def: deduction; such meaning which are to be reasoned out or guessed from the statement by one's own intelligence
statements which are absolute, not differing from context to context and could not be modified.
an illustrative statement which explains a subject matter with the help of an example understandable to common man
injunction; statements in the form of command or orders which are to be followed strictly without doubt or discussion
decisive statements which establish a conclusion, settlement of a subject after detailed consideration of all relevant and related facts
statements which elaborate a theme briefly said with a detail of description
specific description with such example which could be understood only by experts
initial submission to be counter argued

w_trans: negation of arguments of the opponent
w_def: statements which deny a certain opinion and objects the other's views

partial or brief description of a topic but not fully elaborated there, for risk of going out of context in view of vast detail and referred to other places in the text of details; description of a part of the elaborative subject; contextual application
statements which specifies the main idea, chief purpose of a particular science or method; objective for which the actions are initiated or for which various measured are adopted
repetition of statements when another occasion demands; repetitive statement due to contextual significance

w_trans: union, compounding, formation of a sentence (syntax)
w_def: arrangement or orderly collection; arrangement of sentences by putting the different word and clauses in proper order so as to obtain the correct meaning
statements wherein some word(s) are found missing, which has to be supplied or supplemented appropriately to get the exact meaning of a sentence in that context
statement(s) which do not fix a rule rigidly but give option for a suitable variant
right interpretation; statements for proper arrangement of subject, views in an orderly manner
consideration of the opposite of what is expressed
statements which elaborate a subject matter in detailed
indefinite statements which leave doubt as to the final and correct opinion
words, sentence or paragraphs where in a multitude of things possessing some common property are grouped together and enumerated

w_trans: possibility, statement showing source of origin

w_def: the meaning of certain words which are peculiar to any science wherein they are used in a different sense other than their usual popular meaning.
application of knowledge of one phenomenon happening elsewhere or the extension of a principle enunciated at one place to many other places
technical rules for argument or debate

w_trans: failure to make a submission at appropriate moment
w_def: when the matter which actually to be said earlier but is said later, and because of delayed presentation become unacceptable
the statement which does not leave any scope for further questioning
enquire something relating to a scripture or a part, a question or a part with a view to testing the knowledge, power of comprehension and expression and capacity to reply to the later
the statement which is beset with defects of speech and which requires clarification.

w_trans: acceptance of situation as it is
w_def: accepting of desired as well as undesired situations
unsaid idea conveyed by the said one
statement which is not relevant to the context

w_trans: confirmation of the fact by logical statement which brings the conclusion
w_def: step of discussion and interpretation of hypothesis which bring the argument nearer to the truth which is one of the five steps of establishing statement
censure or reproach; the loop-holing of another's reasons with regard to fallacies and invalid reasoning
fraudulent or delusive statements and unmeaning verbosity
to argue and defend one's own view in a debate
inquiry or investigation to explore something
deduction or conclusive statement; step of inference for re-establishment of truth
loopholes of a competitor by which opponent can be defeated in a discussion
correcting the defects pointed out in respect of a previous statement
the statement that has to be proved; the first step of inference and establishment of truth

w_trans: giving up a proposition or argument
w_def: shift from the original stand; contradiction of one’s own statement being attacked by opponent

w_trans: establishing own hypothesis by logically refuting the hypothetical statement of the opponent
w_def: giving a contrary meaning to a given proposition
question upon question; cross-examination; leading question(s)
a statement with deficiency in any of the five constituents of a sentence and does not convey the proper and complete meaning
the statement is free from any syntactical impurity and express the exact meaning of the sentence
vehemently refuting other's views without considering them
the process by which ascertainment is made
justifying a proposition on the basis of reasons, instance, and conclusion
fallacy of reason: Giving of an irrelevant reasoning instead of relevant reasoning
a demonstrated truth established after repeated examinations and reasoning by scientists

w_trans: theory of increase by similar and decrease by dissimilar
w_def: An applied principle of āyurveda which is used for maintaining the equilibrium of the body constituent which states that similarity causes increase and dissimilarity causes decrease

w_trans: common theory for all school of thought/scripture/ branches of science
w_def: common theory accepted by school of thought or branches of science

w_trans: theory particular to a specific school of thought/scripture/ branch of science
w_def: the particular doctrine made by some school of thought or science and not accepted by other science
six primary schools of philosophy which serve as the theoretical basis of āyurveda viz.,  saṅkhya, nyāya, vaiṣeṣika, pūrvamīmāṁsa, uttaramīmāṁsa
the philosophy promulgated by maharṣi Kapila, dealing enumeration of basic constituents of the universe; a philosophy to declare the truth properly
the branch of philosophy promulgated by maharṣi Goutama dealing with epistemology.

w_trans: philosophy deals with union of the soul and the supreme
w_def: the branch of philosophy promulgated by maharṣi Pataṅjali dealing with union of the soul and the supreme.

w_trans: philosophy for knowledge of specific features
w_def: the branch of philosophy promulgated by maharṣi  Kaṇāda dealing with the study of objects of knowledge

w_trans: philosophy for performance of vedic rituals
w_def: the branch of philosophy promulgated by maharṣi Jaimini dealing with performance of vedic rituals

w_trans: philosophy for knowledge part of Veda which are known as Upanishad
w_def: the branch of philosophy promulgated by maharṣi  Vedavyāsa dealing with knowledge part of Veda known as Upanishad.

w_trans: the doctrine which states that the effect is existent in its cause before production
w_def: the doctrine which proposes that, the effect is always resides in cause even before its manifestation

w_trans: the doctrine which states that the effect is non-existent in its cause before production
w_def: the doctrine which proposes that, the effect is not present in the cause
concepts in which invariable causes are given for one effect

w_trans: theory of spontaneous/ unprompted origin of the universe
w_def: the doctrine which proposes that, effect is produced sequentially after the sequential destruction of the cause
the doctrine which proposes that, nothing is stable or permanent and everything’s undergoes through continuous process of decaying

w_trans: theory of ‘Brahman’ as the only truth
w_def: the doctrine of the Vedānta philosophy which proposes that, ‘Brahman’ is the only truth and the rest is illusion
the doctrine of the buddhism which believes that natural destruction is inevitable to everything
doctrine of transformation which states that all the substances get changes continuously
the doctrine which explains about the transformation at physical plane
the doctrine which explains about the transformation at molecular level
entities which exists (astitvam), are knowable (jñeyatvaṁ), and are denoted with a name (abhidheya); the meaning of a word or group of word
the six knowable objects which are 1. Sāmānya  2. Viśeṣa  3. Guṇa  4. Dravya 5. Karma and 6. Samavāya

1. the attribute which always adds-up/ increases 2. that is which establishes unity 3. an attribute that is having a similar motive (tulyārthata); 4. one that is eternal, one in number and resides in various places.

w_trans: similarity at the level of substance
w_def: similar substances e.g. human flesh having similarities with animal flesh, and which can nourish muscle tissue.

w_trans: similarity at the level of qualities
w_def: similarity between qualities e.g. seminal tissue (śukra) and milk have similar qualities

w_trans: similarity at the level of action
w_def: action adding up to increase of certain entity e.g., sleep increasing kaphadoṣa

attribute that causes depletion/decrease (hrāsahetu); that causes diversity (pṛthaktva) opposite to that of similarity (sāmānya); the one, which resides in eternal draya and differentiates one from the other

w_trans: dissimilarity at the level of substance
w_def: a substance which on consumption/ usage can deplete particular substance

w_trans: dissimilarity at the level of qualities
w_def: qualities acting opposite to each other resulting in depletion of one of them e.g., vāta getting pacified with usage of sesame oil by virtue of its opposite qualities

w_trans: dissimilarity at the level of action
w_def: an activity which causes depletion/ reduction e.g. physical exercise reducing kaphadoṣa, which otherwise is increased with inactivity
quality of a substance; it is an inseparable entity with substance (dravya); guṇa is devoid of any action on its own, however guṇa is responsible for action through dravya
three chief principle attributes; indicative of three mental attributes (sattva, rajas and tamas)
one among the three qualities (sattva, rajas and tamas) which is characterized by lightness, knowledge and enlightenment
one among the three qualities (sattva, rajas and tamas) which is characterized by activity, initiation, action and attachment
one among the three qualities (sattva, rajas and tamas) which is characterized by darkness and ignorance
elemental character responsible for smell of a substance; trait of pṛthvimahābhūta
elemental character responsible for taste of a substance; trait of jalamahābhūta
elemental character responsible for perceivable form by sight; trait of agnimahābhūta
elemental character responsible for touch an substance; trait of vayumahābhūta
elemental character responsible for sound, word; trait of ākāśamahābhūta; also denotes authoritative text (āgama)
properties of substances that relates with the body; extensively used for the selection/ preparing formulae and employing successfully
the quality of a substance which is responsible for nourishment (bṛṁhaṇa) e.g. black gram (māṣa)
the quality of a substance which promotes lightness and decreases the bulk of the body e.g., green gram (mudga)
the quality of a substance which is responsible for the slow activity or delayed response e.g. guḍūci, āmalaki
the quality of a substance which is responsible for quick activity e.g. bhallātaka, marica, dantī
the quality of a substance which is responsible for promoting coldness, promotes stiffness (staṁbhana) and acts as styptic or astringent e.g., uśīra, candana
the quality of a substance which is responsible for promoting sweating, softening/ ripening (pāka) e.g. citraka, cavya
the quality of a substance which is responsible for imparting smoothness, moisture and oily nature to the body e.g. ghṛta
the quality of a substance which is responsible for dryness or which results in absorption of moisture.
the quality of a substance which is responsible for wound healing e.g. haridrā, abhraka
the quality of a substance which is responsible for reducing corpulence e.g. vacā, śilajatu
the quality of a substance which is responsible for gratifying/ satisfying effect.
the quality of a substance which is responsible for stirring up/ churning (viloḍana) and moistening
the quality of a substance which is responsible for bringing about softness or fragility e.g. godhuma,  eraṇdataila, yaṣṭhimadhu
the quality of a substance which is responsible for firmness/ hardness e.g. aśvagandha, śatāvarī, pravāla
the quality of a substance which is responsible for spreading out/ penetration e.g. madhu, saindhava etc.
the quality of a substance which is responsible for closure/ concealment, bulkiness e.g. curd (dadhi)
the quality of a substance which is responsible for concentration/ immobility/ strength to the body and especially to hair, moustache, bones, nails, teeth etc. e.g. balā, atibalā, godhūma
the quality of a substance which is responsible for movement/ stimulation (preraṇa), normal movements such as peristalis
the quality of a substance which is responsible for cleaning and help tissues free from vitiated substances e.g. niṁba,  māṁsarohiṇi
the quality of a substance which is responsible for coating effect over the tissues eg. kumārī, mocarasa
the power of forming and retaining conceptions and general notions, intelligence, reason, intellect, discernment, judgment
favourable perception including happiness, delight, joy, pleasure
unfavourable perception including unhappiness, sorrow, grief
desired attributes produced from seeking of pleasure
aversion - one among the suppressible urges
the quality through which stimulus for useful activity is obtained
group of ten properties commencing with paratva; often used in for analytical purposes and decision making
priority or superiority of a substance over the other innumerable substances
inferiority of substance over the other innumerable substances
the quality which enables us to quantify/ calculate
combination of two or more than two substances
the quality by which one substance is differentiated or separated from the other
the quality by which measurement of various substances is possible
an activity as per plan/ scheme by logic i.e. rational plan
the process through which some change/ transformation is brought to the original properties of any substance
getting used to/ repetitive action leading to development of a habit
an entity encompassing the attributes of quality and action
elementary substances that are said to be the cause of manifestation of all other substances; nine in number
perceptible substances; tangible source substances; also denoted by: settled into any fixed shape, formed, substantial, material, embodied, incarnate
an entity which is responsible for hardness
an entity which is responsible for fluidity
an entity which is responsible for heat
an entity which is responsible for movement
the faculty through which indriya (cognitive organs) connect with the ātman (soul)
internal system of perception and cognition; it is inclusive of manas (mind); buddhi (intelligence);  indriya (cognitive organs);  ahaṁkāra (ego)
having dimension of a paramāṇu i.e. minute entity
being only one in number i.e. there is no possibility of any other entity which functions like manas in the body
the functions of mind viz., thought, analysis, contemplation, mediation and volition
it is the consideration about worth doing or otherwise
it is a critical analysis with reasoning about happening or non-happening
it is a process of proposing possible deduction after analysis
an objective to be pondered over
developing a dogmatic attitude; a goal determined with its merits and demerits
power of retention/ resolution; stable, controlling intellect
rembrance of the things directly perceived, heard (scriptures) or explained earlier. It is the result from a particular conjunction between the soul and mind and also from impression.
six mental attributes that lead to bondage of the soul viz., desire, anger, greed, delusion arrogance and jealousy
desire or of love or of pleasure; also one among the four  puruṣārtha (goals of life)
insatiable desire for having something; excessive desire to acquire more than need
confused state of mind that doesn’t lead to correct perception
state of being emotionally aroused and worked up
intolerance to the good of others/negative competitiveness
denotes the negative roll of pride, haughtiness; also one of the principles of the evolution in the sense of conception of one's individuality, self-consciousness
a natural inclination or fondness for something; that which belongs to or is contained in anything else, an attribute
also denoted by: modesty, bashfulness, embarrassment
also denoted by: propriety of conduct, decency, modesty, mildness
the faculty of distinguishing and classifying things according to their absolute properties
a state of ill-being due to loss of children or affliction or misfortune
also denoted by: deluding, infatuating, leading astray
also denoted by: freedom from perplexity, confusion
also denoted by: arrogance, haughtiness, insolence, conceit
not settled into any fixed shape, form, substance or material
an attribute of a substance characterised by non-obstruction.
soul or spirit: principle of life and sensation, the individual self; the only conscious element in the human body
the soul in association with the living body
in this context it denotes soul
ātma does not actively participate in any action, it merely performs the duty of a witness
relating to self or to the soul
the subtle body which consist of manas: mind, indriya: organs and atma: soul, devoid of gross body; causal body; subtle body
the personal and animating principle in men and other beings, the soul or spirit
unmanifestated state, unapparent, indistinct, invisible, imperceptible.
absolutely autonomous; having no control by others

w_trans: person as the object of treatment
w_def: person as the object of treatment, consisting of five mahābhūta  and ātma
body composed of 24 elements viz., five mahābhūta, the five organs of sense, five organs of action, five tanmātra, avyakta,  buddhi, ahaṁkāra and manas
also denoted by: not experienced, unobserved, unknown, unsanctioned; the invisible result of works done in former states of embodied existence; unseen consequences of an act.
rapid conjugation of mind with sensory or motor organs
inactiveness of ātma, indicating its principle quality of staying as a mere witness to what is happening
being everywhere, all pervading, an attribute of ātma
a process or state whose beginning cannot be ascertained
everlasting, all time existence; innate, native
the quality of soul which is devoid of all bodily and psychological ailments
the power of having an irresistible will, one of the supra normal psychic power derivable from the practice of yoga
living beings having internal consciousness i.e. their consciousness is not externally manifested; e.g. plants
liberation, cessation from worldly existence or transmigration, the fourth puruṣārtha (goal of life)

state of self-realization of ultimate reality. It eliminates all miseries and leads to liberation. It results in the emergence of true knowledge by which the soul transcends the ego and all worldly miseries come to an end.
attaining salvation while one is alive or in the exiting birth itself
one among the nine kāraṇa dravya
effectual substances that are manifestations of the nine causal substances
animate substances; substances having consciousness like plants, animals
animate substances which can feel from within but cannot not express outside e.g. plants
plant which does not bear visible flowers also called as apuṣpa (flowerless) such as uduṁbara  (Ficus glomerata), vaṭa (Ficus benghalensis)

w_trans: plant bearing fruits as well as flowers
w_def: plant which bears visible flowers and fruits such as  āmra (Mangifera indica),  jambū  (Syzyigium cumini)
plant which bears visible flowers and fruits such as  āmra  (Mangifera indica),  jambū  (Syzyigium cumini)
twinner, plant which crawl or small non climbing plant; these are of two types - latā (climber) and gulma (shrub).
twinner/climber e.g. vidārī (Pueraria tuberosa), kapikacchu (Mucuna prurita)
small non climbing/ calling plants e.g. atibala (Abutilon indicum), śāliparṇi (Desmodium gangeticum)

w_trans: plants which die after bearing fruits
w_def: plans which perish after bearing fruits or after harvest; usually annual herbs like paddy, pulses, wheat, maize
living being belonging to animals kingdom which tangibly react to the external stimuli.
animals which have placental birth e.g., man, lion, tiger, cow, goat
oviparous animals e.g. reptiles, birds, fish

w_trans: born of heat and moisture akin to sweat
w_def: creatures which flourish in humid environment e.g. flies, mosquitos, ants, worms
smaller creatures which dwell underneath mud e.g. frogs
non-living; inanimate substances lacking consciousness, e.g. minerals
subtle and rudimentary state of mahābhūta
the eternal and inseparable relationship i.e. relationship between mahābhūta and their qualities
non existence of a substance before its manifestation
non existence of a subject after its destruction
absolute non-existence in past, present or future
non-existence of a substance in another substance
modes of examining and acquiring knowledge; measure
investigation or examinations which leads to correct knowledge
the cognition arising at the instant of the conjugation of the soul, mind, senses, and object
process of sequential contact of indriyārtha (object of cognitive organs), indriya (cognitive organ), manas (mind), and ātmā (soul) to obtain the direct perception
the process through which the knowledge of the unseen facts is inferred on the basis of direct observation
relating to or depending on special qualities, limited by particular conditions, valid only under particular suppositions
type of inference in which perception is got by negative concomitance
type of inference in which perception is got by positive concomitance
type of inference by which perception is obtained for self knowledge
type of inference by which perception is obtained for others

w_trans: improper reason appearing identical to the subject
w_def: improper reasoning while deducing an inference in a particular context; a kind of fallacy of inference; one of the ahetu
a process of drawing inference based on analogy
one aspect or party of discussion; a specific assumption; fortnight; wing
inherent and inseparable adherence between the two things

w_trans: five steps to derive a conclusion through inference
w_def: a collective term used for deriving intended inference based on five steps viz., pratijñā, hetu, udāharaṇa, upanaya, nigamana
categorical examples which can be equally understood by both wise and lay person
the word or the part of sentence where the actual meaning is lying
an affix used to denote a particular inclination, tendency or habit; seventeen types of tācchilya are described.
the one which initiates action independently; also denoted by hetu: cause, karma: doer; it is of three types viz., samavayīkāraṇa, asamavāyi-kāraṇa, nimitta-kāraṇa
intimate or primary cause e.g. a cloth is vowed by threads. in this case threads are the primary cause for making of the cloth
secondary or non inherent cause e.g. in case of the making of the cloth, threads are primary cause and colour/dye etc., are secondary cause
associate cause; instrumental cause; efficient cause e.g. in case of making of the cloth, looms, the weaver etc., are generative cause

ten important aspects for examination viz., kāraṇa  (cause); karaṇa (instrument);  kāryayoni (source of action);  kārya (action itself);  kāryaphala  (fruits of action);  anubandha  (subsequent manifes

in the context of cikitsāśāstra  (medicine), the kāraṇa (cause) is considered as physician, as he/she is the causative factor for the achievement of the object i.e. the maintenance of the equilibrium of dhātu
the tool for treatment i.e. medicine/procedure
intimate cause of illness e.g. disturbance of the equilibrium of dhātu
The process undertaken for the attainment of dhātusāmya (health). i.e. the process of treatment
the outcome of intervention in the form of healthy state; result of the act is attainment of happiness. It is known by satisfaction of mind intellect, sense organs and the body
the long term consequences/ result; in this context it is achievement of healthy longevity
ability to take quick and proper decision as per time and need
both the land as well as the patient constitute deśa (habitat)
both the year consisting of seasons and the state of disease
beginning the treatment or therapeutic action
excellence of the physician and the correctness of the therapy constitute upāya or means of action
the physician is a person who is a dakṣa (expert in medicine);  tīrthāttaśāstrārtha (academically qualified);  dṛṣṭakarmā (experienced) and śuci (purity).
the study of structure and function of the body
indicative of the continuous process of decay of the bodily tissues
indicative of growth in the bodily tissues
whole body comprising limbs, trunk, head and neck

w_trans: factors responsible for the growth of the body
w_def: there are four factors for growth of body:- kālayoga (appropriate time), svabhāvasaṁsiddhi (innate nature), āhārasauṣṭhvam (proper nutrition), avighāta (absence of impairing factors)
a state of all the dhātūs of the body being in normal state

w_trans: factors which are beneficial to the body
w_def: factors which posess properties similar to the body tissues or those which enhance the body tissues when administered within the body
four limbs, trunk and the head and neck
division of the body in to various regions for descriptive purposes
five prominences in the developing foetus corresponding to the four limbs and head

w_trans: part of body below the waist
part of body above the waist
part of body above the clavicle

w_def: generally used as a synonym of head
site where prāṇa and indriya are situated, the uppermost and chief part of the body
area on the sides of the forehead
the anterior part of the head below the hairline and above the eyes
the bony pyramid-shaped cavity of the skull that contains and protects the eyeball
thin fold of skin that covers and protects the human eye
the junction points in the eye such as sclero-corneal junction, the medial and lateral canthi, the junction between eye lashes and eyelids, pupilary margins etc.
medial angle of eye; the angle at medial side of the slit between the eyelids
the angle at the outer end of the slit between the eye lids

w_trans: junction of cilia with lid margin
w_def: point of junction of cilia with lid margin

w_trans: junction of palpebral and bulbar conjunctiva
w_def: it denotes the area where the eyelid and the sclera of the eye meet
circular junction where the cornea meets the sclera of the eye
the inner border of the iris that forms the edge of the pupil
meeting point of upper and lower eyelids
outer and inner angels of the eye; the angle at either side of the slit between the eyelids

w_trans: outer junction of the eye lids
w_def: the junction at the angle at lateral side of the slit between the eyelids
the angle at lateral side of the slit between the eyelids
transperant liquid contained in the anterior and posterior chambers of the eye
a duct connecting nose to the lacrimal apparatus
the liquid excreted into the eyes by the lacrimal glands
structures concerned with secretion and conduction of tears
small canals concerned with conduction of tears from the lacrimal puncta to the lacrimal sac
a duct that conveys tears from the lacrimal lake to the lacrimal sac

w_trans: nerves of the levator palpebrae superioris
w_def: nerves of the levator palpebrae superioris from oculomotor
the arch of hairs growing on the raised elevation at the junction of the forehead and the orbit
stiff hair on the margin of the eyelid
free end of a stiff hair on the margin of the eyelid
root of a stiff hair on the margin of the eyelid

the tough, white outer coat of the eyeball, covering approximately the posterior five-sixths of its surface, continuous anteriorly with the cornea and posteriorly with the external sheath of the optic nerve.
the part of the eye which appears black in colour

the colored contractile membrane suspended between the lens and the cornea in the aqueous humor of the eye, separating the anterior and posterior chambers of the eyeball and perforated in the center by the pupil
aperture of the iris for entry of light into the eye
the five different layers or coverings of eyeball
the clear transperant anterior portion of the fibrous coat of the eye composing about 1/6th of its surface

the colored contractile membrane suspended between the lens and the cornea in the aqueous humor of the eye, separating the anterior and posterior chambers of the eyeball and perforated in the center by the pupil

w_trans: regulatory functional factors of the body
w_def: Principal constituents of the body those are responsible for homeostasis, when present in the state of equilibrium. Doṣa also determine the psycho-physiological nature / constitution of an individual. Doṣa are capable of vitiating the different bodily tissues, when deviate from the state of equilibrium and can lead to diseases. These are of two classes: a. śārīrika (bodily):  vāta, pitta and kapha. b. mānasa  (psychological): raja and tama.

w_trans: three regulatory functional factors of the body
w_def: combined term for all the three doṣa

w_trans: doṣa responsible for movement and cognition
w_def: one of the three bodily doṣa, that is predominant of vāyu and ākāśa mahābhūta. This is a vital biological force that performs the fuctions like all sensory perceptions, all motor activities, and higher mental activities. This is of five subtypes:  prāṇa, vyāna, udāna, samāna and apāna.

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of vāta (vāyu) that is seated in head
w_def: one of the five subtypes of vāyu that is seated in head. It performs the functions like controlling the intellect, heart, sensory and motor organs and mind. It also regulates the activities like respiration, spitting, sneezing, belching and swallowing.
a nectar-like vital entity present in the atmosphere, indicative of oxygen
also denoted by filled with life; spirit; vitality
the combined term for both inspiration and expiration

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of vāta (vāyu), that is seated in thorax
w_def: one of the five subtypes of vāta (vāyu) that is seated in thorax. It performs the functions like effort, strength and recollection required for the production of speech

w_trans: a subtype of vāta, that is seated in hṛdaya
w_def: subtype of vāta, that is seated in hṛdaya. It is responsible for the circulation of rasa from hṛdaya to all parts of the body.

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of vāta (vāyu) that is seated in proximity to agni
w_def: one of the five subtypes of vāta (vāyu) that is seated in proximity to agni (in between stomach and large intestine). It performs the functions like receiving the food, digestion of the food, division of the food into useful and waste portions, and propulsion of the food

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of vāta (vāyu), situated in the pelvic region
w_def: one of the five subtypes of data (vāta), situated in the pelvic region. It performs the functions like defecation, micturition, parturition, menstruation, and ejaculation
combined term for functions of vāta doṣa such as utsāha, uchhvāsa, ceṣṭā etc.
enthusiasm, motivation, effort, activness, to have willingness to do adventure

a function of prāṇa vāta; the flow of air from the exterior to the lungs due to the contraction of respriratory muscles, mainly diaphragm
a function of vyāna vāta; motor functions of the body including movements of limbs etc.
movements happening within the body such as transportation of dhātu etc.

the movement of eye lid due to action of levator palpebrae superioris supplied by the trigeminal nerve

w_trans: doṣa responsible for regulating body temperature and metabolic activities
w_def: one of the three bodily doṣa that is responsible for digestion and metabolism in the body which is agni mahābhūta predominant. This is of five subtypes:  pācaka,  ālocaka,  rañjaka,  bhrājaka and sādhaka.

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of pitta that is situated in between the āmāśaya and pakvāśaya
w_def: one of the five subtypes of pitta that is situated in between the āmāśaya and pakvāśaya which divides the food into sāra (nutritive) and kitta (waste) portions and also supports other subtypes of pitta

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of pitta that is situated in yakṛt and plīhā
w_def: one of the five subtypes of pitta that is situated in yakṛt and plīhā. This transforms rasa-dhātuḥ into rakta-dhātu

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of pitta that is responsible for vision and perception
w_def: one of the five subtypes of pitta that is responsible for vision and perception. It is of two types- buddhi vaiśeṣika and dṛṣti vaiśeṣika. The former is at the level of intelligence and latter at the level of the sense organ (eye)

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of pitta that causes illumination or shining of the skin
w_def: one of the five subtypes of pitta that causes Illumination or shining of the skin

w_trans: one of the five subtypes of pitta situated in the hṛdaya
w_def: the pitta responsible for seeking of objects desired by the intellect or self esteem
the pitta responsible for functions such as prabhā, pakti, darśana etc.
caused due to agni mahābhūta predominance
sensation associated with the desire for food

w_trans: doṣa responsible for regulating body fluids and keeping the body constituents cohesive
w_def: one among the three doṣa responsible for stability, unctousness, lubrication, immunity, and cohesion. This is predominant of pṛthvī and jala mahābhūta. The five subtypes are avalambaka, kledaka, bodhaka, śleṣaka, tarpaka.

w_trans: one of the subtypes of kapha situated in the chest region

any bodily structure that gets vitiated by aggravated doṣa

w_trans: major structural components of the body
w_def: seven major structural components that stabilize and sustain the body (rasa, rakta, māmsa, meda, asthi, majjā and śukra). The previous dhātu nourishes the next in a sequential fashion. Each dhātu is of two forms: A. sthāyi (stable) and poṣaka(nourishing) B. asthāyi and poṣya dhātu; Each dhātu undergoes a cyclical process of origin, maturation and degeneration.
holding, carrying, preserving, protecting, possessing; Common function of all dhātu; Specific function of asthi dhātu

equilibrium of dhātu which is indicated by absence/alleviation of disorder. Criteria for dhātusāmya  include alleviation of disorder, normalcy of voice and complexion, development of body, increase in strength, desire for food, proper and timely digestion of the food taken, timely sleep, elimination of urine, faeces and semen and overall normalcy of mind, intellect and sense organs

first dhātu among seven dhātu and is dominated by jala; this is pumped out of hṛdaya and continuously circulates all over the body to nourish other tissues; it is of nine añjali in quantity;  vyāna and samāna vāyu help in its circulation. the major function of rasa dhātu  is prīṇana  (nourishing)

second dhātu among seven  dhātu  whose function is jivana (to give life). It is formed in yakṛt (liver) and plīhā (spleen) with the help of rañjakapitta and rakta dhātvagni. This is dominant in agni mahābhūta. It is named so because of its red colour.
one of the functions of rakta dhātu
one of the functions of rasadhātu
third among the seven dhātu, whose function is to provide covering over the skeleton. It is dominant of pṛthvī mahābhūta.
type of tissue composed of contractile cells or fibers
fourth among seven dhātu of the body, whose function is to provide snehana (oleation). It is dominant of jala and pṛthvī mahābhūta designative of adipose tissue and other lipids in the body.

fifth of the seven basic dhātu, whose function is to provide stability to the body. It is predominant of pṛthvī and ākāśa mahābhūta. It is comparable to bone tissue (specialized form of dense connective tissue consisting of bone cells embedded in a matrix made of calcified intercellular substance).
central or core part of bone
short bones such as carpal bones, tarsal bones etc.
articulation or junction between two bones
cavity within the bone containing marrow
point of junction between two bones
sixth of the seven basic dhātu, whose function is to fill the bony cavities. It is predominance of jala mahābhūta; the soft organic material that fills the cavities of the bones.
filling up, completing, something used to fill a cavity or container. The primary function of majjā dhātu.

seventh dhātu having the function of reproduction which is generally equated with semen; present in two forms: former pervading the entire body and the latter which fertilizes the ovum. It is dominant in jala mahābhūta.
part of śukradhātu which forms the ejaculate and carries the male gametes
female sexual entity capable of developing into a new individual of the same species when fertilized by spermatozoa

essence of all seven dhātu, that is vital for life characterized by bala (immunity). It is of two types: 1. para, which is present in the hṛdaya and 2. apara, which is present all over the body. The ten attributes of ojas are:  guru  (heavy),  śīta  (cold),  mṛdu  (soft),  ślakṣṇa  (smooth),  bahala  (abundant),  madhura (sweet),  sthira  (stable),  prasanna (bright),  picchila  (sticky) and  snigdha (unctuous).

w_trans: the minor structural components that stabilize and sustain the body
w_def: by-products of convertion of one dhātu to the next which are essential for the body. Unlike dhātu, they do not transform further into another dhātu.
upadhātu of rasadhātu which is dominant of jala mahābhūta and nourishes the baby

monthly periodic physiological uterine bleeding through vagina, with the duration of 3-7 days symbolizing the forthcoming fertile period; also used in some contexts for ovum and the functionality of female reproductive hormones and also.
a band of fibrous tissue connecting muscle to a bone. Kaṇḍarā is an upadhātu of raktadhātu.

w_trans: any tubular vessel of the body

w_def: unctuous portion of pure māṁsa which is the upadhātu of māṁsa dhātu

one of the fundamental constituent of the human body along with doṣa and dhātu which include the various waste products formed during various stages of digestion and metabolism.  Mala are of two classes: āhāramala and dhātumala. āhāramala include mūtra (urine) and purīṣa (faeces). Following are the dhātumala: kapha from rasa,  pitta from rakta, mucus of nose and ear wax from the māṁsa,  sveda (perspiration) from the  meda, nails and hair from the asthi, rheum of the eye from the majjā.
by-products of metabolism which are to be eliminated from the body
one of the āhāramala, the function of which is to support the body in general and vāyu and agni in particular
one of the āhāra-mala whose function is to carry away kleda (watery waste) from the body
mala of meda dhātu whose function is to withhold kleda (watery portion) in the skin
waste products of the body especially faeces

classified in 3 types: sahaja – hereditary, yuktikṛta- gained from exercise, food, rasāyana etc. kālaja – natural strength attained during visargakāla i.e. varṣā ṛtu (rainy season) , śarad ṛtu (autumn) and hemanta ṛtu (early winter)
immunity attained by artifitial means such as rasāyana
strength of the body attained by virtue of favourable season, such as hemanta ṛtu (early winter)

structural or functional channels meant for the transportation of dhātu undergoing transformation having appearance similar to the dhātu that it transports. They are of two types: sthūla (macro) and aṇu (micro).
the external and internal openings of the body
passages for air inside the body

w_trans: channels carrying prāṇa/ channels of respiration/respiratory system
w_def: channels which carry prāṇa throughout the body which originate from the hṛdaya and circulate throughout the body. It is compared to the respiratory system and the diseases of prāṇavahasrotas are to be treated on the basis of treatment principles of respiratory diseses like śwāsa.
also includes the channels with physiological importance in regulation of menstrual cycles (hypothalamo-pituitary-ovarian axis)
pathways which originate from the tālu or kloma through which fluids circulate throughout the body
pathway for inhaled and exhaled air extending from the external nares to the alveoli
channels carrying food which is in the process of digestion
channels which carry and distribute the primary products of digestion to nourish the various body tissues which originate from the hṛdaya and rasavaha dhamanī.
originates from the yakṛt and plīhā. Some of the diseases involving this srotas include kuṣṭha, visarpa, raktapitta, vidradhi etc.
originates from the snāyu and tvacā
originates from vṛkka and vapāvahana and is associated with diseases such as sṭhaulya
originates from vṛṣaṇa and śepha and is associated with diseases such as klaibya.
channels in which urine is formed and excreted which originates from the vasti and vaṁkṣana and is involved in diseases such as prameha, mūtrakṛchra, aśmari etc.

w_trans: channels in which faeces is formed and excreted
w_def: originates from pakvāśaya and sṭhūlaguda and is involved in diseases such as atisāra, pravāhikā etc.

all factors responsible for digestion and metabolism / transformation having predominance of agnimahābhūta. This is of three classes: jatharāgni bhūtāgni and dhātvagni. The intensity of āgni is influenced by doṣa and is of four types: viṣama (irregular due to the dominance of vāta),  tīkṣna (intense, due to the dominance of pitta), manda (depressed due to the dominance of kapha) and sama (normal, due to the balanced state of all three doṣa).
factors responsible for digestion and metabolism / transformation

w_trans: metabolic factors located in digestive tract
w_def: agni responsible for digestion of food in the gastro intestinal tract
agni located in the dhatu responsible for transformation of one dhātu into another namely  rasāgni, raktāgni,  māṁsāgni,  medo-agni, asthyagni and śukrāgni

w_trans: metabolic factors acting at the level of mahābhūta
w_def: five types of āgni, those act after jāṭharāgni, but before dhātvagni on the food and its metabolites. They are: pārthiva, āpya, taijasa, vāyavya and nābhasa. They act on the corresponding substrate based on mahābhūta composition to make them homologous to that of the bodily constituents.
state in which the action of agni is normal due to a balanced state of all the three doṣa
state in which the action of agni is considerably intensified due to dominant influence of pitta
state in which the action of agni is rendered erratic (either excessive or decreased, variable from time to time) due to the dominant influence of vāta
state in which the action of agni is weak/depressed due to dominant influence of kapha
capacity to digest the consumed food

capacity of food intake; the quantity of the food which does not disturb the physiological function of an individual. This differs from person to person and time to time, it directly depends on the digestive fire and psychological status of the person.
division of stomach capacity into three parts,such as one portion of the space for solid items, one for liquids and one part to be left empty for vāta, pitta and kapha
process of digestive / metablic transformation occuring mainly because of the action of āgni
nutrient portion formed during various processes of biotransformation
three phases of correspondingly producing kapha, pitta and vāta
arbitrary division into interior and exterior parts for descriptive purposes
superior (proximal) and inferior (distal) classification of the body for descriptive purposes
anterior (ventral) and posterior (dorsal) classification of the body for descriptive purposes
dependending on the dominance of doṣa, depending on the ability to digest the food, and depending on the bowel movements, the koṣṭha of an individual can be classified as krūra, mṛdu and madhyama

physiological type of koṣṭha produced because of the dominance of either kapha, or due to the balanced state of all the three doṣa. The individual with this type of koṣṭha passes normal bowels and has normal digestive ability
physiological type of koṣṭha produced because of the dominance of pitta. The individual with this type of koṣṭha passes soft bowels and has good digestive ability
physiological type of koṣṭha produced because of the dominance of vāta. The individual with this type of koṣṭha, passes hard stools and has irregular digestive ability
natural urges for elimination which are of two types dhāraṇīya  (suppressible) such as greed, anger etc and adhāraṇīya (non suppressible) such as sneezing, sleep etc.
natural urges of the body which should not be supressed
measurements of the body in terms of height,breadth and length described in proportions of width of individual's fingers

the term signifies disease or ailment which brings about grief or pain to the individual; the word meaning implies an abnormal state of distress or pain, wherein the mind resolves to counteract the disturbances in the body to bring a healthy state. vyadhi brings about distress to physical and mental wellbeing of individual
the structure of the word signifies the diseases originating in the body secondary to disturbances in the process of digestion, due to accumulation of āma in body channels
the term implies diseases that arise out of multiple factors simultaneously.
the term signifies that disease makes life miserable by causing fear, terror or distress in the person.
the term implies diseases characterised by a constellation of symptoms which occur together.
jwara is the most important among diseases and here the term implies the ability of a disease to cause anguish to mind and body.
vikara is the condition which causes deviation from the normal physiological state of health of an individual.
literally, the opposite of ease, when something is wrong with a bodily function. an interruption, cessation, or disorder of functions at the level of psyche, mind or body.
the term literally signifies disease, originating from physical or mental si ns of the individual in present or past life. .

a disease that gives rise to another disease and still continues to exist. it can also signify a condition when two or more diseases co-exist together and may produce as a result of similarity in etiology, or pathogenic mechanism.
the term signifies the categorization of diseases as per various criteria.
the diseases which affects the psyche, can be classified as rajasika and tamasika
disorders of psyche caused by increase in rajo guna in the individual such as excessive anger, jealousy etc
disorders of psyche caused by increase in tamo guna in the individual such as grief, slothfulness, excessive sleepiness etc
classification of somatic diseases on the basis of vitiation of sareerika doshas
this term implies diseases caused by vitiation of pitta dosha such as amlapitta, raktapitta, kamala etc.
this term implies diseases caused by vitiated kapha dosha in the body such as aruchi.
this term implies diseases produced by vitiated vata dosha in the body such as sandhivata, gridhrasi, pakshaghata etc
three fold classification of diseases by acharya susruta on the basis of etiology.
this term signifies diseases produced as a result of affliction of psyche and body, all psychosomatic diseases are included in this categorisation.
diseases caused due to morbidity of sperm and ovum and all hereditary diseases are classified under this.
hereditary anomalies inherited through maternal genetic defects due to morbidity in ovum
hereditary anomalies inherited through paternal genetic defects due to morbidity in sperm
diseases that occur at the time of birth due to improper dietetics and life style practices followed by mother during conception and various stages of foetal development.
congenital disorders that occur in infant due to dietary indiscretions of the mother practiced during conception and pregnancy.

w_trans: diseases due to non-fulfilment of special cravings of the mother
w_def: the congenital or other diseases that occur in the infant due to non-fulfillment of mothers cravings during pregnancy.
diseases that manifest in the body due to vitiation of body humors such as jwara, raktapitta etc.
diseases which have their origin in the gastro-duodenal tract such as amlapitta(hyperacidity), chardi(vomiting ).
diseases which have their origin in the large intestinal tract such as arsas(piles), udavartha(constipation) etc
diseases caused in the body due to exogenous or traumatic causes such as injury from accidents, fall or from animal bite or poisons.
diseases caused by trauma such as accidents, falls etc.
diseases caused by weapons or instruments such as swords, surgical instruments, stones, wood etc.
the diseases which are produced due to attack and bite of tame and wild animals and include attacks by animals and injuries caused by their nails, horns and bites, snake poison, bee sting etc.
diseases that arise out of disturbances in nature such as natural calamities, seasonal or climatic variations or due to tempestuous divine interventions such as floods, epidemics, draught etc.

diseases that are manifested in the body due to abnormal variations in the climate such as due to excessive rain, excessive heat, excessive cold and include conditions such as heatstroke, frost bite etc.

w_trans: diseases caused by abnormality of the season
w_def: diseases that manifest in the body due to unexpected variation in the character of seasons such as excessive rain during rainy season, excessive snowfall during winter etc.

w_trans: diseases which are not caused by abnormality of the season
w_def: the diseases that are caused due to vitiation of body humors that are consistent with that of a normal season and manifests mainly because of non-adaptation of suitable dietetics and regimen prescribed for that season.

diseases that are believed to be caused by divine or supernatural causes without any other apparent cause and includes diseases caused by destruction by natural calamities such as floods, cyclones etc.

w_trans: diseases caused by lightning and thunder
w_def: diseases caused by natural disasters such as thunder, lightning, asteroids and fall of comets on earth surface
diseases caused by ominous evil forces such as spirits etc are included in this.

diseases that are caused and transmitted in individuals by close contact or by being in proximity with individuals affected with some diseases such as kushta( leprosy), netrabhisyanda( conjunctivitis) etc
the diseases which manifest suddenly in the body without any apparent cause.
a variety of diseases, brought about by natural progression of bodily processes such as hunger, thirst, sleep, old age etc.
the diseases that manifest in the body naturally due to the effect of time and physiological progression such as ageing, wrinkling, greying of hair etc.
the conditions that manifest prior to their natural time of occurrence in the body due to improper dietetics, erratic lifestyles etc such as premature greying and wrinkling etc.
the classification of diseases based on their prognosis such as good prognosis(sadhya), incurable(asadhya), curable with difficulty( krichrasadhya) and palliative (yapya)
diseases having good prognosis such as chardi (vomiting), mandagni ( depleted digestive fire).
easily curable diseases, having less causative factors, less amount of vitiation of doṣa and manifested in comparatively less deteriorated body tissues.

the diseases that are curable with difficulty owing to various factors such as multiplicity of etiological factors, depleted strength of individual, diseases involving multiple tissue; including diseases such as piles caused by involvement of two body humors.

the diseases which are incurable owing to involvement of all body humors, multiple tissues and tracts and presenting with arishta lakshana(signs that are markers of impending death) and includes diseases such as urdhwaswasa(severe respiratory disease), hemorrhagic diathesis due to all humors etc
the diseases which by nature are not completely curable , but only palliable with suitable medicines and dietetics such as prameha(obstinate urinary disease), tamaka swasa(bronchial asthma ) etc.
the diseases which could not be managed at all even with excellence of medicine, physicians, health etc.
diseases caused due more than one vitiated dosha
examination / investigation of the disease; it is carried out with the help of païcalakshananidana

the fivefold factors that help in understanding and diagnosis of a disease, including etiology(nidana), purvarupa(prodromal symptoms), rupa(signs and symptoms of the disease), samprapthi(pathogenesis) and upasaya(understanding of aggravating and relieving factors)
the factors that directly or indirectly act as aetiology of a disease.

the term literally means causative factors of the disease. ayurveda gives immense importance to understanding the cause of the disease and mentions evading the cause as prime and important measure in preventing or curing a disease. they are classified into different categories.
synonym of nidana which literally means sakuna(omen or prognostic).
synonym of nidana which means cause of disease.ayatana also means the site which provide shelter .
synonym of nidana which literally means the perpetrator; that which act as cause of disease
synonym of nidana meaning cause; used in terms of faith also
literal meaning of the word implies origin/progress of a disease which would point to its aetiology
the two fold type of aetiological factors that is based on the nature of etiology as those which directly cause disease and those which act as additional cause in manifestation of disease
etiological factors that act as direct cause for the initiation of a disease by favouring accumulation of respective doshas
etiological cause that sustains the aggravation and stimulates progression of a disease
external causes that include vitiation of dosha through alterations in food, behavioral aspects and time
internal factors like doṣa, dushya that exist inside the body which act as the ultimate cause in disease manifestation, when deviated from normal stage of equilibrium
causes leading to disturbances in the anatomy and physiology of the body
causes leading to disturbances in the functions of mind
classification of etiology into three types including asatmyendriyartha samyoga (improper use of sense organs), prajnaparadha(intellectual blasphemy) and parinama (transformation attributed to time)
misuse of the senses in wrongful manner, in excess or in less than normal way; included as one of the three prime causes of a disease

w_trans: intellectual blasphemy; knowingly opting the wrong things may be dietetic or behavioural
w_def: included as one of the three prime causes of a disease; the misuse of a person’s intellect in identifying the wholesome / beneficial thing, any act done bereft of intelligence, perseverance and mindfulness. such an act aggravates all the three doṣa thus should be avoided by a wise person

w_trans: seasonal variation as a cause of disease
w_def: the negative impact of the season; included as one of the three prime causes of a disease

w_trans: vitiated doṣha as a cause of disease
w_def: the seasonal variations causing natural accumulation and aggravation of the doṣa
the normal physiological state of dosa which brings about state of equilibrium and health in body

w_trans: deviation of doṣha from its normal state
w_def: the deviation of dosa from normal physiological state of equilibrium with derangement of functional, qualitative or quantitative aspects of dosa which is the basis for disease
independent disease having its own set of symptoms and classical line of therapy
any disease which does not have an independent existence or line of treatment
state of normalcy in any aspect without any deviation or derangement from normal state, function or quality
not normal; differing in any way from the usual state, structure or condition

w_trans: phenomenon of propulsion of normal dosha to another site to produce its symptoms
w_def: specific term which represents a pathological phenomenon when vitiated vata dosa forcefully shifts another dosha from its normal site to another and produces symptoms

w_trans: the physiological and pathological movement of doṣa within the body
w_def: the movement of doshas within the body(apart from physiological movement) is a pathogenic mechanism which results in manifestation of disease in different tracts

w_trans: way of the movement of doṣa
w_def: the term signifies spread of the vitiated dosha

w_trans: movements of doṣa from viscera to tissues
w_def: movements of doṣa towards tissues (shakha), either physiological or pathological; manifestation of diseases occur when the vitiated dosas gets dislodged in sakha

w_trans: movements of doṣa towards vital parts, head and junctures and junctions of the body
w_def: movements of doṣa towards vital parts, head and junctures and junctions of the body

dosa when associated with ama undergoes qualitative and functional alteration and become capable of producing diseases. Äma: The term is used as a technical word for anything that exists in a state of incomplete transformation. It is mentioned in various contexts like a) In particular, it can refer to a toxic by product generated due to improper or incomplete digestion. b) Toxins that were produced at any stage of metabolism and that are circulating through the channels are also sometimes. c) The first stage of any disease is also frequently. d) Any substance which is present in its abnormal state and is unwanted in the body. It represents, in a gross sense, mere indigestion which begins in the stomach, to, in a finer sense, even a faulty enzymatic pathway that prevents or hampers a metabolic cycle or chain. It is a very important factor playing a pivotal role in the genesis of any disease. It is also important in determining the prognosis, drug selection and all other stages of therapy.
when ama associated with any dosha undergoes depletion, the resultant dosha is termed as nirama, which is still in vitiated state and has not returned to normalcy
causes which aggravate doṣa irrespective of the disease
factors that cause a disease irrespective of the doṣa involved in it

w_trans: causes which aggravate doṣa as well as disease specific causes
w_def: factors which not only aggravate particular dosha but also cause for a particular disease; causes affecting both mind and body
the classification of hetu as four types based on its capability in producing disease
the potent cause which can directly cause a disease i.e. ruksha diet is the sannikrishta nidan for vatika type of jwara
distant causative factors which are comparatively less influential in causing a disease i.e. rudra kopa (wrath of god rudra) is said as viprakrushta hetu for jwara
non – dominant causative factor; thus cannot independently cause a disease and may produce when suitable situation arises in body
dominant causative factors which play dominant role in causing a disease; such factors produce instantaneous dosha dushti and are very potent in causation of disease e.g. poison
it is the premonitory symptom by learning about which one can avoid the manifestation of the disease; depending on their nature they are classified into two types
classification of prodromal symptoms on the basis of their general and specific nature, which points to any disease or any particular disease
they signify two meanings a) specific symptom pertaining to particular dosha. b) those premonitory symptoms which convert into signs and symptoms of a particular condition.
they signify two meanings a) general premonitory symptoms b) those premonitory symptoms which does not convert into signs and symptoms.
any morbid phenomenon or departure from the normal in structure, function, or sensation, experienced by either the patient or physician and indicative of disease syn: li~gaga
various synonyms of linga such as lakshana, chihna, akrti etc
synonyms of liṅga; denotes the symptoms that is manifested in a disease.
synonyms of liṅga; any morbid phenomenon or departure from the normal in structure, function, or sensation, understood by physician which is indicative of disease.
synonyms of liṅga; signs which points toward any disease such as krichraswasanam (difficulty breathing) pointing towards swasa roga ( respiratory disease)
synonyms of liṅga; literal meaning denotes the type of manifestation in the body
synonyms of liṅga; this term denotes the manifestations of disease
synonyms of liṅga; any morbid phenomenon or departure from the normal in structure, function, or sensation, understood by physician which is indicative of disease.

w_trans: symptoms seen in the body after the complete expulsion of the impaired doṣa
w_def: the symptoms and signs that points to a normal state after the expulsion of vitiated doshas.
the signs and symptoms of improvement signifying relief / alleviation of the disease.
classification of assuagement on the basis of their nature

w_trans: drug ,food, behaviour aspects that are antagonistic to causative factors of disease
w_def: judicious use of medicines, regimen and dietetics that is antagonistic to the etiology of disease

w_trans: drug ,food, behaviour aspects that are antagonistic to disease
w_def: judicious use of medicines, regimen and dietetics that is antagonistic to the nature of disease itself.

w_trans: drug ,food, behaviour aspects that are antagonistic to both causative factors of disease and disease itself
w_def: judicious use of medicines, regimen and dietetics that are antagonistic to both the etiology and disease itself.

w_trans: drug ,food, behaviour aspects that are similar
drug , food, behaviour aspects are similar to causative factors of disease
w_def: judicious use of medicines, regimen and dietetics that is similar to the etiology, but capable of producing assuagement

w_trans: drug ,food, behaviour aspects that are similar to disease
drug ,food, behaviour aspects that are similar to both causative factors of disease and disease itself
w_def: judicious use of medicines, regimen and dietetics that is similar to both the etiology and disease, but capable of producing assuagement.

intervention of the diet and medicine which is neither good for health nor for diseases. and it is one of the tools of the diagnosis where the diseases cannot be diagnosed by referring merely its clinical features.
the term signifies the mechanism starting from vitiation of doṣa till the origin and complete manifestation / development of the disease. further pathogenesis is classified into six types.
classification of the pathogenesis according to enumeration.
classification of the pathogenesis according to primary or secondary ailment

classification of the pathogenesis according to the categorization based on various aspects such as based on prognosis a disease can be classified as saadhya (easily curable), aasadhya( incurable), krichsaadhya(difficult to cure) etc.
classification of the pathogenesis according to the predominance of one or other fraction of the three doshas
classification of the pathogenesis according to strength of the disease
classification of the pathogenesis according to time of occurrence or aggravation of the disease

the diseases that develop subsequent to a disease or during the course of the main disease that is being treated, and is dependent upon the main disease for its origination, nature and the strength. it is called secondary in the sense that its onset follows the presence of the primary disease
complications caused during therapeutic procedures like panchakrma (eg. basti vyapada)
complications that arise during treatment due to non- obedience from the side of the patient
complications that arise by the false application of medical or surgical procedures
complications which arise as a result of improper usage of drugs, usage of poor standard drugs etc.
fatal sign and symptoms which arises in patients denoting poor prognosis or death
the term signifies different stages of diseases.

w_trans: ripened stage of doṣa in a disease
w_def: the transforming phase of a disease-course or vrana denoting post- inflammatory condition /suppurative condition of a disease or vrana.
the transforming phase of a disease-course or vrana denoting the inflammatory condition.
state when the ama state is converted by either the effect of time or therapeutic measures

w_trans: stages of disease manifestation and its management
w_def: six chief stages in the management of diseases/ step wise description of a disease’s pathogenesis.
it is the first stage of kriyakala. the stage of accumulation of doshas in their own place (swasthana)
it is the second stage of kriyakala. the stage of provocation or aggravation of the doshas.
it is the third stage of kriyakala. prasara means leave & spread and thus it is the stage of migration of vitiated doshas from their usual places to different places.

it is the fourth stage of kriyakala. the term literally means taking shelter in a place. it is the stage of disease augmentation wherein the vitiated doshas lodges into other body parts consisting of khavaigunya(vacant space) and causes functional, structural or both deformities.
it is the fifth stage of kriyakala. the stage of symptom manifestation of the disease.
it is the sixth stage of kriyakala, the stage of complications and here the symptoms can be differentiated on the basis of doshas.
examination of patient done by darshan(observation), sparshan(palpation) and prashna (interrogation).
examination of patient done by five senses and interrogation.

eight folds examination of patient as : 1. examination of pulse (nadi)2. examination of urine (mootra) 3. examination of the excreta (mala) 4 . examination of tongue (jihwa) 5. examination of voice, sounds produced from body like percussion etc. (shabda) 6. tactile examination (sparsha) 7. examination of eyes and eyesight (driga) 8. examination of the body stature (akruti)

ten folds of examination considering below mentioned criteria: 1. physical constitution (prakruti) 2. morbidity (vikruti) 3. excellence of dushya or tissue elements (sara). 4. compactness or tissues or organs (samhanana) 5. measurement of body constituents (pramana) 6. homologation (saatmya). 7. psycic condition (satwa) 8. power of intake and digestion of food (aaharshakti) 9. power of performing exercise (vyayam shakti) 10. age (vayah)
resisting power of the body, which reacts to arrest the progress, occurrence, and reoccurrence of diseases
natural, non-specific type of immunity which defends the body in the first occurrence of any disease.
body’s defence mechanism which checks the occurrence or reoccurrence of diseases.
complete or partial obstruction in the body channels leading their malfunctioning.
the term physiological or structural signifies deformity in the body channels leading to manifestation of the diseases.

w_trans: causes of deformity in the body channels
w_def: the term signifies the etiological factors for the deformity in the body channels
types of the deformity in the body channels

w_trans: increase or over flow of the contents in the body channels

w_trans: obstruction due to contraction of lumen
w_def: obstruction in the pathway of body channels which restricts the movements and may also forms a collateral way sometimes

w_trans: diversion to the flow of the contents to the improper channels
w_def: diversion to the flow of the contents to the improper channels

w_trans: occurrence of nodular growth in the body channels
w_def: occurrence of nodular growth in the lumen of body channels
literally, it signifies parts or items that are grouped together. generally the term is used to state the involvement of all the three doshas, in the pathogenesis of diseases.
the simultaneous appearance of two or more illnesses.
the term literally means abode , place where diseases take shelter and from where manifestation of disease occurs.
the abnormal state of the vitiated doṣa where in they become concealed in the body channels and remain opportunistic to cause abnormality in the body in presence of a favourable condition.

w_trans: movement of dosha from its usual place
w_def: syn: agantu doshah ref.code: 1.137.0 dosha when moves to other place and shows disease manifestation there.

w_trans: dosha residing at its usual place
w_def: the term literally means inhabitant dosha, that is dosha residing at its own place.

w_trans: the disease in which symptoms manifest in accordance to dosa involved
w_def: a disease caused due to sannipaata, in which dosha dominance can be understood on the basis of symptoms

w_trans: the disease in which symptoms other than that of dosa involved also manifested
w_def: a disease caused due to sannipaata, in which dosha dominance cannot be understood on the basis of symptoms

w_trans: material or substance used for therapeutic purpose or health benefits
w_def: akin to the term ‘drug’ in modern pharmacology; substance wherein properties and actions embodies in an inseparable manner and is the substratum for rasa, guṇa, vīrya, vipāka and prabhāva
branch of Ayurveda which deals with substances used for health benefits in all their aspects like properties, actions, uses, sources, processing, quality etc.
factors which make dravya superior or more important that guṇa, vīrya etc.
dravya is relatively stable than its properties and actions
fact of dravya being more eternal than guṇa and karma
dravya remains the same even though guṇa and karma change by processing
perceptible by all five senses i.e. dravya can be percieved by all five senses
an attribute of being the substratum of properties and actions
action initiating ability of dravya, only dravya can initiate any action, not their properties
texts describe dravya as more important than guṇa, karma etc.

w_trans: dependance of guṇa and karma on state of dravya
w_def: properties and actions of a substance depends upon the state of dravya
different parts different effects; properties and actions are specific to the part of the substance;
texts containing various information of medicinal substances like synonyms, pharmacological properties and actions
the branch which deals with the nomenclature and morphology of dravya
seven criteria on the basis of which dravya are named
tradition based nomenclature of plants or popular usage
naming a plant based on its specific action like kṛmighna etc

w_trans: five attributes of dravya beginning with rasa
w_def: five attributes of dravya viz., rasa, guṇa, vīrya, vipāka, prabhāva
direct and immediate action of a dravya when it comes in contact with the tongue which are six in number and determined by its pāñcabhautika composition
one among the six types of rasa which is most pleasing to tongue e.g. sugar
one among the six types of rasa which is acidic or sour in nature e.g. lemon
one among the six types of rasa which is saline in nature e.g. common salt
one among the six types of rasa which is pungent in nature e.g. pepper
one among the six types of rasa which is bitter in nature e.g. bittergourd
one among the six types of rasa which is astringent in nature e.g. black plum
latent taste of a dravya which is either not perceived or is perceived towards the end of its contact with the tongue
rasa which even though present in the dravya is not perceived by the tongue

guṇa refers to the properties of drugs and dietary articles which are responsible for their respective action in the body and is defined as the characteristic by which people are attracted towards a particular substance

potency of a drug in terms of dominant guṇa classified into two viz.uṣṇa(hot) and śīta (cold) or eight viz. guru, snigdha, śīta, mṛdu, laghu, rūkṣa, uṣṇa and tīkṣṇa by which the drug brings out the therapeutic effect or action
quality of a substance characterized by its gentleness
state of temperature which is neither hot nor cold
having strong or higher grade of potency
substances which have a moderate degree of potency
vipāka is the rasa of the drug after it has undergone digestive and assimilative transformations which is classified into three viz. kaṭu (pungent) amla (sour) madhura(sweet)
an exceptional or unique therapeutic effect of a dravya by which drugs having similar rasa, guṇa, vīrya and vipāka have different therapeutic actions
action of dravya which is determined in order of significance by the prabhāva, vīrya, vipāka and rasa of that dravya
therapeutic action which kindles the agni but cannot digest the āma
process by which the undigested food, doṣa, āma etc are digested
therapy which neither removes doṣa from the body nor increases normal doṣa but only corrects the imbalance of doṣa
therapeutic action of digesting or transforming the undigested materials (food, doṣa etc.) and propels them downward by acting as mild laxatives or normalizing the physiological movements of doṣa
kind of purgatives which separate and remove the undigested substances and toxins adhered to the linings of the intestines without digesting them
purgatives which breaks down the hardness of stool and eliminate them
class of purgatives which liquefies the doṣa and eliminate them or substances that expels excreta by increasing its liquid content;
expelling out vitiated doṣa and mala through various body openings viz mouth, nose, anus, etc
therapeutic action which forcefully separate the doṣa completely and remove them out of body
therapeutic action which dries up body tissues and then literally scraps up the unwanted substances out from the body
substances with therapeutic action of both dīpana and pācana which dries up excessive liquid portion due to its uṣṇa property

seed-bearing part of a plant, consisting of reproductive organs (stamens and carpels) typically surrounded by a brightly coloured corolla (petals) and a green calyx (sepals)
bud on a plant from which a leaf develops.
fleshy product of a tree or other plant that contains seed and can be eaten as food
powder form of hairs present on the fruit’s outer surface
unit of reproduction of a flowering plant, capable of developing into another such plant
the part of a seed which acts as a food store for the developing plant embryo, usually containing starch with protein and other nutrients
part of a plant which attaches it to the ground or to a support, typically underground, conveying water and nourishment to the rest of the plant via numerous branches and fibres
enlarged structures in some plant species used as storage organs for nutrients
any plant that grows along the ground, around another plant, or up a wall by means of extending stems or branches
a shrub or clump of shrubs with stems of moderate length
plant that spreads over the ground or another plant
woody perennial plant, typically having a single stem or trunk growing to a considerable height and bearing lateral branches at some distance from the ground
a bud on a plant from which a leaf develops.
hard permanent outgrowth, often curved and pointed, found in pairs on the heads of cattle
dense inner part of a tree trunk
