w_def: preparation of medicines, specifically indicating compounds containing plant, mineral and animal origin ingredients

w_trans: science dealing with study of metals especially mercury, minerals and their therapeutic applications
w_def: branch of ayurvedic pharmaceutics in which various metals, Minerals and other substances, including mercury, are purified and combined with herbs for therapeutic purpose

adjunct administered either along with or just after the principal medicine to enhance its therapeutic action. (When administered with the principal medicine it is described as Sahapāna, though in practice, the term Anupāna connotes both)
process adopted to remove the residual doṣa and to enhance the therapeutic action of drugs (as in the case of Tāmra Bhasma)

w_trans: black mixture of mercury and sulphur
w_def: when sulphur (gandhaka) is added to mercury (pārada) and triturated without adding any liquid till it becomes a very fine black powder, akin to Aethiops Mineralis

powder of āśudhanya such as kulmāṣa, ṣaṣṭika rice etc., along with small quantity of white radish (mūlaka), cut into pieces, and placed in an closed earthen pot with water and kept for two to three weeks making a sour fluid called kāṅjika, dhānyāmla or ār

w_trans: processing by heating medicines in glass flask/bottle
w_def: process by which, formulations are prepared in a kāca kūpi which, is heated as directed
desired drug is taken with eight or sixteen times of water and boiled with mild heat until one-eighth remains then filtered and boiled again to get a semi solid concentrate

desired drug is washed well with water and cut into small pieces and added with four times water and boiled on mild heat till one-fourth water remains and then filtered and further heated till the water is evaporated and the decoction is reduced to a semi

w_trans: process to remove ām and gandha doṣa from ghṛta
w_def: ghṛta is boiled in a vessel till it becomes free from froth and cooled. The kalka (paste) of desired drugs is added and boiled with mild heated to remove ām and gandha doṣa from ghṛta

w_trans: powder made from dew drops collected from caṇa plant
w_def: dew drops appearing on caṇa plant (Cicer arientinum) are collected and evaporated by heating until a very small amount remains and further dried by keeping the vessel under sun to make a powder
filtrate obtained by mixing 60ml of water with 250 mg of lime powder, keeping for 9 hours and then filtering through a filter paper after decantation

various methods for purification of the desired drug (like nirmalīkaraṇa of ṭaṅkaṇa where part of the drug is added to specific amount of water and filtered and the filtrate is boiled to evaporate the water and dried to remove moisture completely)

w_trans: pouring molten metal into a liquid
w_def: process of process of pouring molten metal into specified liquid
liquid obtained by mixing 48 gm of rice with 385 ml of water keeping for two hours and thereafter decanting
decanted liquid obtained from a mixture of equal quantity of crushed barley and warm water kept over night

w_trans: process to remove gandha doṣa from taila
w_def: tila taila is taken in a vessel and boiled till it becomes free from froth then it is cooled and then added with water and the kalka of desired drugs and boiled till water content is lost, it removes gandhadoṣa (undesired smell) from oil
process of fumigating a pot or a vessel with the prescribed drugs

w_trans: inability to revert back into its metal form
w_def: property of bhasma from which it cannot be reverted to its metallic form (even if mixed with mitrapañcaka and heated to the temperature at which the bhasma is prepared)

w_trans: immersion of heated solid in liquid
w_def: process of immersing the heated solid ingredients in a specified liquid
thin flakes prepared from kajjali by heating and melting it with or without other drugs
fine powder of drugs added to a kalpa such as leha, Āsavāriṣṭa etc. to enhance taste, palatability and bioavailability of the drug
drug or herbs which can be used in unavailability of desired drug
process of giving heat by keeping it under the sun like evaporation of water from a medicinal preparation by exposing to sun

w_trans: pulverization by adding a liquid to a powder
w_def: process by which powders of drugs are pulverized to a soft mass with liquid substances and allowed to dry to enhance its properties
triturating of drugs to a fine state of division with or without prescribed liquid
process by which metals and minerals are grinded with liquids and then dried and made into bhasma by heat

w_trans: procedure for removal of āma and gandha doṣa of taila/ghṛta
w_def: procedure for removal of āmadoṣa of taila/ghṛta and gives colour and fragrance
special kind of vessel used in satvapātana etc. It is generally prepared with burnt husk, china clay etc. after making them into a soft pulp
desired drug is made into decoction which is filtered and then concentrated to make a thick syrup of phāṇita (raw jaggery) like consistency similar to ghana
liquid obtained by subjecting the bundled mass of lākṣā (Laccifer Lacca) in six times of water in dolāyantra and straining it, twenty one times
process of removal of impurities and potentiating of drugs
process of fermentation of liquid with desired drugs
sealing the edges of a vessel, with the lid on, at the point of contact, with a paste of clay and cloth
supernatant liquid containing self generated alcohol obtained from fermentation any cooked cereal, prasannā is the clear supernatant portion Surā
heating of desired substance in a pan under fire (pāka of lauha made in a sthāli (iron pan) on strong fire)
when heated materials attain atmospheric temperature in situ by itself
various forms in which medicine are made
fine paste of the fresh herbal drug
decoction obtained by boiling coarse powder of drug(s) in specified proportions of water and reduced to certain amount
fine sieved powder of well-dried drug(s)
juice extracted after heating a bolus of herbs covered in various substances at a desired temperature
the infusion obtained by pouring boiling water on the powdered drug(s) and used after filtering
juice of fresh plant material obtained by various methods
the infusion obtained by keeping overnight the desired herb powder in cold water and used after filtering
measure of heat in terms of various heating arrangements meant for preparing various kinds of bhasma
an arrangement using eight cow-dung cakes as fuel (vanyopala)
an arrangement of heating in a pit of 90 cm in length, breadth and depth filled cow dung cakes
an arrangement of heating in a pit of 60 cm in length, breadth and depth filled with cow-dung cakes
an arrangement of heating of the size that is half of a gajapuṭa
Instrument; equipment; Machine for the preparation of various types of medicines
an alchemical apparatus for distillation used to make arka
mortar with pestle, made of various stones in different shapes and sizes
an alchemical apparatus in ḍamaru shape for sublimation
an alchemical apparatus for distillation of various drugs like Mercury with the delivery tank weld to it obliquely
iron ladle, with a long handle

w_trans: instrument for giving heat by suspension of drug in liquid
w_def: an alchemical apparatus consisting of a pot half filled with specified liquid with a horizontal rod placed on the rim from which the bundle of material to be treated will be immersed and heated
big-mouthed hollow earthen vessel filled with sand used to heat layered kāñca kūpī
main eight procedures used for purification and potentiating pārada from its raw form to medically useful form and also for metallurgic procedures
one of the aṣṭa pārada saṁskāra, sudation of pārada (generally done in dolāyantra)
one of the aṣṭa pārada saṁskāra, trituration of pārada (generally done in khalvayantra)
one of the aṣṭa pārada saṁskāra, where pārada is triturated to the level so as to remove all its impurities (vahni, mala, viṣa) and pārada become inactive (mūrchita or swooned)
one of the aṣṭa pārada saṁskāra, where pārada is potentiated again from inactive (mūrchita or swooned) form of pārada done by sudations with various drugs
one of the aṣṭa pārada saṁskāra, various procedures of distillation of pārada (three types Ūrdhvapātana, Adhahpātana and Tiryakpātana) done after utthāpana
subtype of pātana samskara where distillation is done in upward direction
subtype of pātana samskara where distillation is done in downward direction
subtype of pātana samskara where distillation is done in oblique direction

one of the aṣṭa pārada saṁskāra, procedure to remove impotency of pārada by reducing impurities, which occurs due to its previous samskara (done by various methods including sudation, keeping it in salt water in a earthen pot etc.)

w_trans: procedure to control mobility of pārada
w_def: one of the aṣṭa pārada saṁskāra, where paste of various drug with pārada kept in desired liquid and is bundled in a poṭṭali and sudation is done by dolāyantra to control its mobility which was imparted due to bodhana saṁskāra

w_trans: procedure in which pārada is made capable of amalgamating other entities
w_def: pārada after niyaman saṁskāra mixed with various herbs is subjected to sudation in dolāyantra to make it capable of swallowing, digesting or amalgamating other entities

various interventions such as drugs, procedures and life style modifications used for the management of various disease conditions
one among the eight clinical branches of āyurveda. It deals with management of generalised systemic diseases
all factors responsible for digestion and metabolism / transformation
treatment which eradicate or normalise the impaired dośa and establishes the equilibrium of all the dhātu restoring the normal structure and function of bodily elements
synonym of cikitsā; Removal of disease e.g. jvara nivṛtti in jvara
synonym of cikitsā; the dietary and behavioural practices helpful in treating the disease or maintaining health. e.g lāja in chardi

w_trans: practice towards mitigating the cause and effect of the disease

synonym of cikitsā; therapeutic measures by which the disease is cured and health is restored

synonym of cikitsā; atonement to cure the diseases caused due to wrong deeds [also mentioned as a type of daivavyapaśraya cikitsā]

synonym of cikitsā; process of restoration of health

synonym of cikitsā; the process by which the disease is ward off
one of the classifications of treatment; spiritual therapies are incantation of mantra, talisman, wearing of gems, auspicious offerings, gifts, oblations, atonement, fasting, going to pilgrimage etc.

w_trans: treatment through chanting of auspicious hymns

administration of proper diet for the management of diseases
administration of medicines for the management of diseases
antonym of medicine; substances with adverse effect to health
one of the two types of abheṣaja e.g. poison, burn by fire or cut by sharp instrument etc. that produce immediate effect after their use

w_trans: detrimental to health in long term

the procedures or medicines used to improve health and longevity
one among the eight clinical branches of āyurveda concerned with aphrodisiac management
medicine which cures the ailments of a patient

a broad classification of therapeutic measures into two sub categories - santarpaṇam and apatarpaṇam
a procedure of alleviation of disease by nourishing of bodily tissues
a procedure of alleviation of disease by depletion of bodily tissues

one among the ṣaḍvidhopakramāḥ; procedure which is nutritive/ nourishing/ increasing body weight / growth promoting or bulk enhancing

one among the ṣaḍvidhopakramāḥ; procedure that induces lightness in the body
process by which the metabolic fire is enhanced
process by which the undigested food, doṣa etc are digested

process of keeping the person thirsty as a therapeutic measure
process of exposing the person to wind as a therapeutic measure

process of making the person to exercise as a therapeutic measure
one among the ṣaḍvidhopakramāḥ; procedure that induces dryness

a type of lepa (anointment) which is moderate in thickness

w_trans: procedure to eliminate morbid doṣa from body

removal of the doṣa or other harmful substances
creating conditions hostile to the cause of disease
necessary prerequisite for cure and prevention of recurrence of disease

one among the three fold classification of treatment which is antagonistic to disease

measures to bring back from the state of unconsciousness
the word naiṣṭhikīcikitsā is combination of two words  niṣṭhā  (definitive) and cikitsā (treatment), thus naiṣṭhikīcikitsā means definitive treatment or a permanent remedy to disease

w_trans: major purification therapy/ bio-cleansing therapy/ detoxification therapy

w_def: it indicates the individual amount of food articles in the meal plate. it is contrast to sarvagraha. here it refers to the caloric value of individual food articles in the meal plate.

w_trans: alienation and adoption in quarter portion
w_def: unwholesome food practices are to be tapered in quarter / quarter of quarters, and are substituted by pathyahara (wholesome food practice) in interval of one, two or three meal time according to condition. substitution is to be augmented in gradual, phased manner.

w_trans: best time part for taking food
w_def: one should eat when previous meal digested

w_trans: food or drinks consumed by the individual
w_def: food taken in various forms- eaten(ashit), drunk (pita), licked (lidha) and devoured (khadita))

w_trans: ingestion of sufficient quantity of food
w_def: ingestion of sufficient quantity of food which does not cause any disturbance in the body.
quantity of food which does not cause any disturbance in the body.
those who have weak digestive power & who are sick less quantity of food is advisable
consists of sarvagraha (total account), and parigraha (individual account) which ascertain the results of the food taken in proper or improper quantity.
those who have more of fat accumulation in their body, who are unctuous, those suffering from madhumeha, who have more of kapha in body should be treated with dry food.

w_trans: taking an admixture of desirable and undesirable food items
w_def: eating green gram (wholesome) and black gram (unwholesome) at a time.

w_trans: accounting of the quantity of the entire food in totality
w_def: considering all the food articles together in meal plate, which may includes cooked cereals, pulses, condiments, drinkables etc. it refers to the whole caloric value of all food articles of meal plate. it is contrast to parigraha
daily activities and food which have become habitual to body.

w_trans: not taking of food in hurry
w_def: one should not eat food in hurr, it may leads to improper mixing of food with saliva, indigestion and entry of food in wrong tract.

w_trans: not taking of food too slow
w_def: one should not eat too slow by this one doesn't get satisfaction, eats more, food becomes cold and is digested irregularly.
those who have aversion for medicine, it should be given mixed with food.
excellence or abundance of quality of suitability
food which excites the doṣa but do-not eliminate them out of the body and thus becomes inherently antagonistic to the dhātu
food which is antagonistic to the place where it is consumed such as eating dry food in arid areas etc.
food which is antagonistic to the time of consumption such as eating hot and pungent food in summer season
food which is antagonistic to the status of agni such as eating heavy food when agni is weak
food which is antagonistic with respect to dosage such as intake of honey and ghee in equal quantity
food which is antagonistic to the habituation or suitability of a person such as intake of sweet and cold substance by persons accustomed to pungent and hot substance
food which is antagonistic to the status of doṣa
drugs and diets which prepared in a particular way produce poisonous effect such as eating meat of peacock roasted on a castor spit
taking diet and drugs having cold potency in combination with those of hot potency
administration of too little or mild potency drug in person with hard bowels
intake of vata vitiating substance in person indulged in over-work and kapha vitiating food in person who has indulged in oversleep etc.
taking food before passing of bowels etc.
intake of hot things after taking pork etc.
taking cold things after intake of ghee etc.
cooking using bad fuel, undercooking, overcooking etc.
unwholesome combination of food - intake of sour substance with milk etc.
any substance which is not pleasant in taste
unwholesome in richness of quality- intake of substance that are not matured, over matured or putrefied
e.g. not taking food in privacy

w_trans: neutralization of the vortices of feelings
w_def: yoga is neutralization of the vortices of feelings
combined name for yama, niyama, āsana, praṇayāma, pratyāhāra,  dhārana,  dhyāna and samādhicombined name for yama, niyama, āsana, praṇayāma, pratyāhāra,  dhārana,  dhyāna and samādhi

five ‘ethical rules’ or ‘moral imperatives’ viz., ahiṁsā (nonviolence),  satya (truthfulness, non-falsehood), asteya (non-stealing),  brahmacarya(chastity, marital fidelity or sexual restrain),  aparigraha (non-avarice, non-possessiveness). they serve as foundation steps in the path of aṣṭāṅgayoga (eight fold yoga)five ‘ethical rules’ or ‘moral imperatives’ viz., ahiṁsā (nonviolence),  satya (truthfulness, non-falsehood), asteya (non-stealing),  brahmacarya(chastity, marital fidelity or sexual restrain),  aparigraha (non-avarice, non-possessiveness). they serve as foundation steps in the path of aṣṭāṅgayoga (eight fold yoga)

five ‘virtuous habits’, ‘behaviors and observances of conduct’ viz. śauca (purity, clearness of mind, speech and body);  santoṣa (contentment, acceptance of others, optimism for self);  tapas (persistence, perseverance, austerity);  svādhyāya (study of vedas, study of self, self-reflection); īśvarapraṇidhāna (contemplation of the īśvara i.e. the god or supreme being); they serve as foundation step in the path of aṣṭāṅgayoga (eight fold yoga)
a steady, relaxed posture, that one can hold for period of time
process to attain control over the prāṇa: life within the body through control of breathprocess to attain control over the prāṇa: life within the body through control of breath

w_trans: withdrawal of senses from their object(s)
w_def: the process of withdrawing the senses from outside objects, things, persons, or situations

dhāraṇā stands for ‘holding’, ‘concentration’ or ‘one pointed focus’ this can be achieved by deep concentration, with single pointed focus on an object and keeping the mind steady without waveringdhāraṇā stands for ‘holding’, ‘concentration’ or ‘one pointed focus’ this can be achieved by deep concentration, with single pointed focus on an object and keeping the mind steady without wavering
dhyāna may be compared with meditation or contemplation achieving consciousness of being or having become one with the object of meditation
union of self with the supreme or oneness with the subject of meditation
jnana yoga, bhakti yoga, karma yoga, patanjala yoga, hathayoga, dhyana yoga etc. are the types of yoga.
it includes yama (restraint), niyam (observances), asana (postures), pranayam (breathing exercise) and pratyahara (withdrawal)

w_trans: internal or inner path of yoga

w_def: symbolic and ritualistic hand gestures used in yoga which are believed to affect flow of energy in body and unblock chakras
energy flow to a particular area of body is stopped by means of bandha.
six yogic practices involving purification of body viz. dhauti, basti, neti, trataka, nauli and kapalbhati
cleansing of digestive tract achieved by administration of emesis or vomiting
method of colon cleansing by administration of water or air into the intestine
nasal cleansing with the help of water or sterile cloth or thread
gazing at a material, marked point or flame of a candle without blinking the eyes. helps in improving eye sight and concentration.
churning or pumping movement of stomach which tones up the abdominal muscles, organs of the abdomen and removes digestive disorders
purification of the head and brain to make the head or skull radiant
